questions.question: Which of the following groups is not included in the high-risk core population for HIV transmission?

options.C: Men who have sex with men

questions.explanation: high-risk behaviors. IV drug users (IDUs), female sex workers (FSWs), and men who have sex with men (MSM) are considered core populations because they have higher transmission rates and can spread the virus efficiently within and beyond their networks. Long-distance truck drivers (LDTD) are part of the bridge population —individuals who connect the core population to the general population but are not themselves a core group. High-Risk Core Populations for HIV Transmission HIV transmission risk groups are classified into core populations (highest risk) and bridge populations (who facilitate wider spread) . Group Category Rationale IV drug users (IDUs) Core High HIV risk due to needle sharing and risky sexual behavior. Female sex workers (FSWs) Core Engage in frequent unprotected sex , increasing exposure. Men who have sex with men (MSM) Core Higher prevalence of unprotected anal sex , a major HIV transmission route. Long-distance truck drivers (LDTD) Bridge They interact with core populations (FSWs, IDUs) and spread HIV to the general population but are not core transmitters themselves. IV drug users (Option A): Incorrect because needle sharing and risky behaviors place them in the core group . Female sex workers (Option B): Incorrect because FSWs have a high number of sexual partners , making them a key core group. Men who have sex with men (Option C): Incorrect because MSM have a high prevalence of HIV due to unprotected sex , placing them in the core group . Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7857571/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5681713/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5098328/

questions.question: Malaria detection on the field is done by which of the following?
questions.explanation: field settings due to its quick results (15–20 minutes), ease of use, and minimal technical expertise requirement . RDTs detect Plasmodium falciparum-specific HRP2 antigen or Plasmodium lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH) for all species . Unlike microscopy (thick/thin smear) , RDTs do not require a microscope or trained personnel, making them ideal for remote and resource-limited areas . Malaria Detection Methods Method Principle Best Used In Limitations Thick smear Concentrates parasites for better detection Diagnosis in labs with microscopy Requires staining and expertise Thin smear Used to identify species and parasite morphology Differentiating Plasmodium species Less sensitive in low parasitemia HRP2 antigen / RDT Detects malarial antigens (HRP2 or pLDH) Field settings, rapid diagnosis Cannot detect low parasitemia or HRP2-deleted strains Quantitative Buffy Coat (QBC) Fluorescent staining of parasites in WBC fraction High-sensitivity lab settings Expensive, requires specialized equipment Thick smear (Option A): Incorrect because, while sensitive, it requires staining, microscopy, and expertise , making it impractical for field use. Thin smear (Option B): Incorrect because it is primarily used for species identification, not rapid detection in the field . Quantitative Buffy Coat (Option D): Incorrect because it requires specialized equipment and is not feasible in field settings . Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC124834/ Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page.306

questions.question: A fruit farmer presents with fever, respiratory difficulties, and neurological complications. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: contracting due to its association with fruit bats. It presents with fever, respiratory difficulties, and severe neurological complications, including encephalitis, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case. Incorrect Options: Option A - Ebola: Ebola virus primarily causes hemorrhagic fever with symptoms like severe bleeding, multi-organ failure, and shock. While it can present with fever and some neurological complications, respiratory symptoms are not typical, and there is no specific association with fruit farming. Option B - Meningitis: Meningitis causes inflammation of the meninges surrounding the brain and spinal cord, leading to fever, headache, neck stiffness, and neurological complications. However, respiratory symptoms are uncommon, and the condition is not linked to fruit farming. Option D - Zika: Zika virus primarily causes mild symptoms like fever, rash, and joint pain, and is more famous for its complications during pregnancy, such as microcephaly in newborns. It does

questions.question: A man occasionally eats outside due to traveling reasons. He presents to a physician with abdominal pain for 4 days, along with a history of fever and bradycardia. Which test is used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: the early stages of typhoid fever, particularly within the first week of illness. Typhoid fever, caused by Salmonella typhi, is suspected due to the patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, fever, and bradycardia (a feature known as "relative bradycardia"). Blood culture can directly identify the bacteria responsible for the infection. Incorrect Options: Option B - Widal test: The Widal test detects antibodies against Salmonella antigens but is less specific and can yield false positives due to previous vaccination or exposure. It is typically used later in the course of the disease but is not as reliable for an initial diagnosis compared to blood culture. Option C - Stool culture: Stool culture can detect Salmonella in the stool, especially in the later stages of typhoid fever or in carriers, but it is less effective in the early stages of the illness when bacteria are more likely present in the bloodstream. Option D - Urine culture: Urine culture is not typically used to diagnose typhoid fever. While Salmonella can occasionally be excreted in urine, this is not common during the acute phase of the disease.

questions.question: If the incubation period of a disease is 5-14 days, what should be the recommended quarantine period?
questions.explanation: duration to cover the full range of the incubation period, thus minimizing the risk of spreading the disease. Incorrect Options: Options A, B and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.question: The period between the entry of an organism into the host and the time when the host becomes maximally infectious is referred to as?
questions.explanation: organism into the host and the point when the host becomes infectious. It represents the period when the organism multiplies and the host can spread the infection. Incorrect Options: Option B - Median incubation period: This is the time between the entry of the organism into the host and the appearance of symptoms. It does not directly relate to infectivity but to symptom onset. Option C - Window period: This is the time between exposure to an infectious agent and the point when the infection can be detected by diagnostic tests. The person may be infectious during this time, but the infection may not yet be detectable. Option D - Latent period: This is the time from exposure to an infectious agent until the host becomes infectious.

questions.question: A 35-year-old male soldier complained of being plagued by a painful, erosive lesion near his earlobe since his return from his duty in the desert area. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and general physical examinations reveal no other abnormalities. The punch biopsy of the leading edge of the erosion reveals the given findings. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.explanation: painful, erosive lesion near his ear lobe since his return from his duty in the desert area, which points towards the diagnosis of Leishmaniasis. Leishmania donovani is the causative organism for Leishmaniasis Sandfly (Genus Phlebotomus) transmits Leishmaniasis (caused by Leishmania Donovani). Kala-azar/ Black sickness/Dum-dum fever/Sandfly disease/ Visceral Leishmaniasis Organism Protozoan Epidemiology Endemic in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal Types Visceral (Kala-Azar): L. donovani Cutaneous: L. tropica Mucocutaneous: L. braziliensis Post-kala-azar dermal (PKLD): Immune response Reservoir Humans (non-zoonotic) Vector Sandfly (Phlebotomus argentipes): has hairy wings. Environmental Peak outbreak: November to April Mechanism of transmission Bite of sandfly Blood transfusion (rare) Incubation period 10 days to 2 years. (1-4 months average) Clinical features Visceral: Fever, Weight loss, Hepatosplenomegaly, Anemia. Cutaneous: Painful skin ulcers Mucocutaneous: Rapid mucosal destruction of nose and oropharynx PKDL: Skin nodules filled with micro-organisms Diagnosis Rapid diagnostic kits: rk39-dipstick test. Used for field surveys. Biopsy (Gold standard): Leishmania Donovan bodies (amastigotes) Sandfly control measures DDT: 1-2gm/m 2 . BHC (benzene hexachloride) Treatment DOC: Single dose Liposomal amphotericin-B (LAMB)10 mg/kg Alternatives: Miltefosine + Paramomycin Pentamidine Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect, as they do not show amastigotes (LD bodies) which are diagnostic. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 351-356

questions.question: Mark the incorrect statement regarding Nipah virus:

options.A: It is transmitted through bat urine

questions.explanation: Paramyxoviridae and genus Henipavirus . Nipah virus does not primarily cause hemorrhagic fever; its main clinical manifestations are encephalitis and respiratory illness. Out of the given options, this is the most incorrect statement. Nipah virus Natural reservoir Bats Modes of transmission Direct contact with infected animals Body secretion (blood, urine, faeces, seminal fluid) (Option A) Consumption of contaminated food products (palm sap or fruits) Incubation period 4-14 days Clinical features Fever, chills, headache Encephalitis (M/C), acute respiratory distress syndrome Multiorgan failure, GIT haemorrhage (case fatality rate- 40-70%) Incorrect Options: It is present in India (Option C): There have been Nipah virus infection outbreaks in Kerala (2018). It is an emerging infection (Option D): The Nipah virus is an emerging infectious agent belonging to paramyxoviridae. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 407 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK570576/ https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/infectious-disease-topics/nipah-virus-disease/factsheet-nipah-virus-disease#

questions.question: Match the following diseases with their respective incubation period: a. Chicken pox 1. 10-12 days b. Mumps 2. 14-16 days c. Measles 3. 16-18 days d. Syphilis 4. 2-4 weeks (average 21 days)
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) a-2, b-3, c-1, d-4 Explanation: Chickenpox (a-2): Incubation period is typically 14–16 days . Mumps (b-3): Incubation period is 16–18 days . Measles (c-1): Incubation period is 10–12 days . Syphilis (d-4): Incubation period is 2–4 weeks , average 21 days . biphasic illness Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease Coxsackie A virus Feco-oral, respiratory secretions 3–6 days Common in young children Polio Poliovirus Feco-oral, oral-oral 7–14 days May be asymptomatic or paralytic HIV/AIDS (Acute Phase) HIV Sexual, blood, perinatal 2–6 weeks Acute retroviral syndrome during seroconversion Malaria Plasmodium spp. Mosquito-borne (Anopheles) 7–30 days P. falciparum: shorter incubation Tuberculosis Mycobacterium tuberculosis Airborne Weeks to months Latent TB has undefined incubation period Bacillus cereus food poisoning Bacillus cereus Ingestion of contaminated food 1–6 hours Associated with reheated rice Staphylococcal food poisoning Staph. aureus Ingestion of preformed toxin 1–8 hours Common in cream/pastry-based food Botulism Clostridium botulinum Ingestion of toxin 18–36 hours Neuroparalysis; questions.question: A 32 year old male presented to emergency department with crush injury to the hand. He had a TT injection when he was 25 years old. The wound has been cleaned. What is the recommended next step of management?
questions.explanation: immunization. It is the optimal choice for post-exposure prophylaxis in wounds, especially when the patient has taken vaccination <10 years ago. In this scenario, where the patient has a crush injury to the hand and a wound of uncertain cleanliness, the recommended next step is a TT only. Incorrect options: Option B. Td only: Td (tetanus and diphtheria toxoid) is the appropriate choice in this case. Td provides protection against both tetanus and diphtheria. Given the patient's age (32 years) and he took the TT vaccine 7 years back only TT is required. Td should be administered every 10 years as a booster dose, especially after injuries. Option C. TT with Ig: Tetanus toxoid with immunoglobulin is used in cases where someone has not received their primary tetanus vaccination series or if their immunization status is uncertain and they have a dirty or significant wound. In this case, since the patient received a TT injection at 25, adding immunoglobulin is not necessary. Option D. Td with Ig: Adding immunoglobulin (Ig) is not necessary in this case since the patient's last tetanus vaccine was not too long ago (at 25 years old). Td alone is the recommended next step. Reference: .

questions.question: A patient has developed hepatitis A for more than 15 days. What is the correct statement ?
questions.explanation: "acute" typically refers to an illness that is present for less than six months. Since the patient has had hepatitis A for more than 15 days, they are still within the acute phase of the illness. Incorrect Options: Option A - Early Acute: While the patient is within the acute phase of hepatitis A, the term "early acute" isn't typically used to describe the stage of this disease. Option C - Chronic: Hepatitis A does not progress into a chronic, or long-term, infection. This differs from hepatitis B and C, which can become chronic conditions. Option D - Severe: While hepatitis A can cause severe symptoms in some people, the term "severe" isn't used to describe the stage of the disease. Severity would be determined by the specific symptoms and their effects on the patient. Reference: .

questions.question: In which category of bioterrorism, does Anthrax belong?
questions.explanation: classification. Bioterrorism agents are categorized based on their potential threat to national security and public health. Category A agents are considered the highest priority and pose the greatest risk to both public health and national security. Anthrax is one of the agents classified in this category due to its ability to cause widespread illness, panic, and social disruption if intentionally released. Incorrect Options: Option B - CAT B: CAT B agents are the second-highest priority and are considered moderately easy to disseminate and cause moderate morbidity rates. They may have a significant impact on public health. Option C - CAT C: CAT C agents are the third-highest priority and are considered emerging pathogens that could potentially be engineered for mass dissemination. Option D - CAT D: CAT D is not a recognized category in bioterrorism classification.

questions.question: Which of the following is not included in STEP approach?
questions.explanation: refers to a method of evaluating a patient's overall health status. Each letter in "STEP" represents a different aspect that is assessed. The blood group is not usually considered a part of the standard health assessment denoted by the STEP acronym. Incorrect Options: Option B - Blood pressure: Included in the STEP approach. Blood pressure measurement is an important part of assessing a person's cardiovascular health. Option C - Blood sugar: Included in the STEP approach. Blood sugar levels, often measured as blood glucose levels, are a crucial component of evaluating a person's metabolic health, particularly in relation to conditions like diabetes. Option D - Blood lipid: Included in the STEP approach. Blood lipid levels, including cholesterol and triglycerides, are commonly assessed as part of evaluating a person's cardiovascular health and risk of heart disease.

questions.question: A 5-year-old child came to ER presenting with fever, cough, runny nose, and a characteristic red rash.Which of the following statements about measles disease is incorrect?

options.C: Period of communicability is 14 days after rash

questions.explanation: period of communicability for measles is generally considered to be from 4 days before the rash appears to 4 days after the rash onset. The infected person can transmit the virus to others through respiratory droplets during this period, even before the rash appears. Incorrect Options: Option A - Incubation period of 14 days: The incubation period for measles is typically around 10 to 14 days, during which the infected person does not exhibit any symptoms. Option B - Strain used is Edmonston Zagreb: Edmonston Zagreb is one of the strains of the measles virus that has been used in vaccines. It's a weakened, attenuated strain used to induce immunity. Option D - Transmitted primarily through respiratory droplets: Measles is highly contagious and is primarily transmitted through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks. These droplets can remain suspended in the air for some time and can be inhaled by individuals who are in close proximity to the infected person.

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient with known HIV infection and presenting with persistent cough, fever, and weight loss, which diagnostic test is considered the investigation of choice for detecting tuberculosis (TB)?
questions.explanation: molecular diagnostic test that detects the genetic material (DNA) of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is known for its speed and accuracy in diagnosing both active tuberculosis and drug-resistant tuberculosis. This test can provide results within a few hours, which is especially important for patients with HIV or other immunocompromised conditions who are at higher risk of developing severe TB. It can also simultaneously test for resistance to the antibiotic rifampicin, a marker for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). Incorrect Options: Option A - Culture: Culture involves growing the bacteria (Mycobacterium tuberculosis) from a sputum or other clinical sample. While it is a definitive method for diagnosing tuberculosis, it can take several weeks to get results. This may not be suitable for patients who need timely diagnosis and treatment, especially if they are immunocompromised like in the case of HIV infection. Option B - Chest x-ray: A chest x-ray can provide valuable information about the presence of lung abnormalities, such as infiltrates, cavities, or nodules, which might suggest tuberculosis. However, a chest x-ray alone cannot definitively diagnose TB. Additional tests are needed to confirm the diagnosis. Option D - PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction): PCR is another molecular technique used to amplify and detect the DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It can be a valuable tool in diagnosing TB, especially in cases where there is a limited amount of clinical sample available. Like CBNAAT, PCR offers rapid results compared to traditional culture-based methods. Reference: .

questions.question: A 40-year-old male with a known case of HIV infection and a CD4 count less than 50 cells/ µ L. Which of the following infections is he at risk of developing?
questions.explanation: compromised immune systems, especially those with a CD4 count less than 200 cells/ µ L (and in this case, less than 50 cells/ µ L), are at high risk for opportunistic infections. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a severe fungal infection and a common opportunistic infection in individuals with HIV/AIDS, especially when the CD4 count drops below 200 cells/ µ L. With a CD4 count less than 50 cells/ µ L, the patient is at significant risk for developing PCP. Here's an explanation of the other options: Option A. Candida: Candida infections, especially oral thrush, are common in HIV/AIDS patients. However, with a CD4 count less than 50 cells/ µ L, more severe infections are a greater concern. Option B. Staph. aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause skin and soft tissue infections in people with HIV/AIDS. While these infections are common, they are not specific to individuals with severely compromised immune systems. Option C. Disseminated MAC Infection: Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infections can occur in people with advanced HIV/AIDS. However, they are typically a concern when the CD4 count drops significantly below 50 cells/ µ L. The question states the patient's CD4 count is less than 50 cells/ µ L, so MAC infection is a possibility, although Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is of higher concern. Reference: .

questions.question: A 5-year-old child presenting to a clinic with a history of cough, runny nose, conjunctivitis, fever, and a rash that initially arises behind the ears and then spreads to the chest, back, and abdomen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: presents with symptoms such as cough, runny nose, conjunctivitis (inflammation of the eyes), fever, and a characteristic rash. The rash usually starts behind the ears and then spreads to the face, neck, chest, back, and abdomen. This pattern of rash spreading is known as "cephalocaudal progression." Measles is highly contagious and can lead to complications, especially in young children. Incorrect Options: Option B - Dengue: Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral infection caused by the dengue virus. It usually presents with symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, joint and muscle pain, rash, and mild bleeding. However, the rash in dengue typically appears a few days after the onset of fever and is not characterized by the specific pattern described in the question. Option C - Rubella: Rubella, also known as German measles, is a viral infection caused by the rubella virus. It presents with symptoms similar to measles, including rash, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. However, the rash in rubella usually starts on the face and then spreads to the rest of the body. It does not follow the pattern of starting behind the ears. Option D - Chikungunya: Chikungunya is a viral infection caused by the chikungunya virus and transmitted through mosquito bites. It is characterized by symptoms such as high fever, severe joint pain, muscle pain, headache, and rash. The rash in chikungunya is not specific in its appearance and does not have the distinct pattern of spreading from behind the ears as described in the question.

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presenting with hypopigmented patches, loss of cold sensation followed by hot, touch and pain along with a palpable ulnar nerve. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Mycobacterium leprae. It affects the skin and peripheral nerves, leading to various sensory and motor impairments. The patient's presentation of hypopigmented patches (pale or light-colored skin areas), followed by loss of cold sensation, then hot sensation, as well as touch and pain sensations, along with a palpable ulnar nerve, is characteristic of leprosy. Leprosy can cause nerve damage and sensory loss, often leading to these specific sensory changes. Incorrect Options: Option A - TB (Tuberculosis): Tuberculosis primarily affects the lungs and other parts of the body, causing symptoms such as chronic cough, weight loss, fever, and fatigue. It does not typically manifest with hypopigmented patches, loss of cold sensation followed by hot, touch, and pain sensations, or ulnar nerve involvement as described in the case. Option C - HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus): HIV is a virus that attacks the immune system, leading to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). While HIV can cause various symptoms and complications, including skin issues, the presentation described in the case (hypopigmented patches, sensory changes, and ulnar nerve involvement) is not typical of HIV infection. Option D - Candida: Candida refers to a group of yeast-like fungi that can cause infections, often in mucous membranes and moist areas of the skin. Candida infections usually present as red, itchy, and inflamed areas, often with a cottage cheese-like discharge. The symptoms of hypopigmented patches, altered sensation patterns, and ulnar nerve involvement are not consistent with a Candida infection.

questions.question: Which vaccines should healthcare workers receive?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hepatitis: Explanationa; Healthcare workers are at increased risk of exposure to bloodborne pathogens , including Hepatitis B , which can be transmitted via needle-stick injuries or contact with blood. Vaccines recommended for healthcare workers (CDC & WHO): Vaccine Reason Hepatitis B Bloodborne transmission risk from patients Influenza Seasonal spread in hospital settings MMR Protection against measles, mumps, rubella Tdap For pertussis, tetanus, diphtheria protection Varicella For non-immune HCWs, to prevent chickenpox COVID-19 For pandemic and endemic control Rabies Only for specific risk groups like lab workers or veterinarians Cholera (Option A): Not routinely recommended unless deployed to cholera-endemic outbreak areas. HPV (Option B): Given for cancer prevention in general population; not specific to HCWs. Rabies (Option D): Only for HCWs working in labs handling the virus or in high-risk zoonotic exposure jobs. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4381171/

questions.question: The blood pressure of a population was tracked from childhood to adulthood. It was observed that those who had lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood, while those who had higher BP in childhood had high BP in adulthood. This can be best described as:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Tracking of blood pressure Explanation: Blood pressure of an individual is tracked from childhood to adulthood in the tracking phenomenon of blood pressure. This is a very useful tool in early diagnosis hypertension even among adolescents/ young adults. If a person is hypotensive in childhood, he remains hypotensive in adulthood. If a person is hypertensive in childhood, he remains hypertensive in adulthood. This phenomenon of persistence of persistence of rank order of bllod pressure has been described as tracking. Tracking of blood pressure Rules of Halves (Option A): The concept of the "Rule of Halves" in hypertension management illustrates that: Approximately 50% of individuals with hypertension are aware of their condition. Among those aware, only about 50% receive treatment. Out of those receiving treatment, approximately 50% have their blood pressure adequately controlled. Stepwise approach (Option C): is a systematic, multi-step method designed to collect noncommunicable disease risk factor data at the population level using a questionnaire, physical assessments, and biochemical tests . Primordial approach (Option D): Focuses on preventing the emergence of risk factors in the first place. Targets social, economic, and environmental conditions that contribute to disease. Focuses on preventing risk factors before they develop (e.g., lifestyle interventions in childhood to prevent hypertension in adulthood). This does not describe the observation in the question.

questions.question: According to the Colombo plan, which of the following statements regarding cancer treatment is correct?

options.A: Help with PET scan units for diagnosis of cancer

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Setting up cobalt therapy units Explanation: The Colombo plan consists of 20 developing countries within the region and 6 non-regional members. Canada made a contribution by setting up Cobalt therapy units . The Colombo plan helps in promoting good living standards for the people of the area by evaluating the developmental plans and coordinating development assistance. The Colombo Plan Multilateral agency. Promotes the concept of collective intergovernmental for economic and social development in South and Southeast Asia. Primary focus is on agricultural and industrial development and sometimes on health. Membership - 20 developing countries. 6 non-regional members - Australia, Canada, Japan, New Zealand, UK, USA. Provides Cobalt Radiotherapy Units to Medical Colleges AIIMS in New Delhi was established with financial assistance from New Zealand. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - Edition 27, Page 1031 Image: https://colombo-plan.org/history/

questions.question: A boys' hostel has an outbreak of fever cases with headache, followed by the development of pleomorphic rashes sparing palms and soles. What is the next best step in the management of suspected cases?

options.A: Isolate for 6 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 72 hours of exposure
options.B: Isolate for 12 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 48 hours of exposure

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Isolate for 6 days Explanation: The probable diagnosis, in this case, is chicken pox, also called varicella, which is caused by the Varicella zoster virus. Control measures include isolation of the child for a period of 6 days after the onset of rashes, and disinfecting all materials that are contaminated by nasal or throat secretions. Parameter Details Chickenpox Seasonal affinity: Winter season Etiology: HHV-3 Route of transmission: Respiratory / aerosol route Age group affected: 5-9 years (school going age) Incubation period: 14-16 days Infectivity: 2 days prior to 5 days after the onset of rash SAR:> 90% Clinical Features Pre-eruptive stage: Sudden onset of mild to moderate fever lasting 2–3 days. Eruptive stage: Centripetal, pleomorphic rash with "Dew drop on rose petal" appearance. Complications Adults/Immunosuppressed: Pneumonia. Maternal varicella: Low birth weight, microcephaly, cataract, deafness, fetal wastage. Secondary bacterial infection: Cellulitis, osteomyelitis, erysipelas. Diagnosis PCR: Detecting VZV DNA. Cell culture: From saliva or vesicle fluid. Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells. Control and Prevention (Options A, B, and D) Isolation: 6 days after rash appearance. Disinfection: Used specimens with infective secretions. Acyclovir: For adults to prevent complications; not indicated in children. VZV Immunoglobulin: Within 72 hours of exposure, for immunosuppressed individuals. Vaccine: 12–18 months of age; 0.5 ml subcutaneous injection. Reference: Park textbook of preventive and social medicine, 25th edition, Pg. no. 156- 159.

questions.question: A 35-year-old homeless man presented with a 1-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest x-ray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management?

options.D: Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ask for CBNAAT Explanation: According to the NTEP guidelines, a negative smear with positive chest X-ray findings would require a CBNAAT. It is the current gold standard for diagnosis of tuberculosis within 90 minutes. Diagnostic Modality Description Usage Sputum Smear Microscopy Microscopic examination of sputum samples to detect acid-fast bacilli (AFB). Used for initial screening and diagnosis, especially in resource-limited settings. Chest X-ray Imaging done to identify abnormalities suggestive of TB. Used to support diagnosis when clinical suspicion is high; not definitive for TB diagnosis. TruNAAT/CBNAAT Molecular tests that detect Mycobacterial DNA and rifampicin resistance. Recommended for initial diagnosis due to high sensitivity and specificity; rapid results. Line Probe Assay (LPA) Molecular test to detect specific genetic mutations associated with drug resistance (e.g., rifampicin, isoniazid). Used for detecting drug resistance in confirmed TB cases, not for initial diagnosis. Tuberculin Skin Test (TST) A skin test to measure immune response to injected tuberculin protein. Primarily used for screening latent TB infection; not specific for active TB diagnosis. Interferon-Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs) Blood cytokine analysis test that measures immune response to TB antigens. Used for detecting latent TB infection Sputum Culture Growing Mycobacteria from sputum samples to confirm TB and test for drug susceptibility. Gold standard for TB diagnosis; takes several weeks to obtain results. Drug Susceptibility Testing (DST) Testing TB bacteria from patient samples to determine resistance to TB drugs. Used to guide treatment by identifying drug-resistant strains in confirmed TB cases. Repeat sputum smears (Option A): Previously it was done but not done after 2016. Repeat sputum smears are taken to monitor the treatment response. Ask for line probe assay (Option C): Line probe assay is usually used for the diagnosis of the first line antitubercular drug resistance tuberculosis and are not indicated in this case scenario. Wait until TB culture results to start ATT (Option D): Since it is slow growth, it takes around 4 weeks to get the sputum culture reports. Hence, it is not ideal to depend on culture reports to start ATT.

questions.question: A patient comes with a history of category 3 dog bites. He received prophylaxis for a monkey bite 6 months back. What is the next step in management?

options.B: Wound cleaning + rabies vaccine on day 0 & 3

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Wound cleaning + rabies vaccine on day 0 & 3 Explanation: A patient previously vaccinated for rabies (within 3–6 months) requires only a booster of two doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3 after a new category 3 exposure. This ensures rapid and sufficient anamnestic immune response without the need for additional interventions like rabies immunoglobulin. Wound cleaning only (Option A) : is incorrect because wound cleaning alone is insufficient for managing a category 3 dog bite, even if the patient was vaccinated earlier. Booster doses of the rabies vaccine are essential to maintain protection. Wound cleaning + rabies vaccine on day 0, 3 & 7 (Option C) : is incorrect because a three-dose schedule is unnecessary for previously vaccinated individuals. The recommended booster involves only two doses (day 0 and day 3). Wound cleaning + IM vaccine + RIG (Option D) : is incorrect because rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is only indicated for rabies-naïve patients or those who have not completed prior prophylaxis. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 319, 320.

questions.question: Which of the following medications is typically prescribed as the initial treatment for tuberculosis during the first 2 months?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ethambutol Explanation: The initial 2-month phase (intensive phase) of tuberculosis treatment typically includes a combination of Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol (HRZE) . Ethambutol is crucial in preventing drug resistance and enhancing treatment efficacy. Streptomycin (Option A) : is incorrect because while it was previously used as a first-line drug, it is now rarely included in the initial treatment due to the rise in drug-resistant TB and toxicity concerns. Linezolid (Option C) : is incorrect because it is a second-line drug reserved for multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) cases, not for initial treatment. Levofloxacin (Option D) : is incorrect because it is also a second-line drug used in drug-resistant TB rather than the initial phase of standard treatment. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 214- 218

questions.question: For which of the following airborne infections is it necessary to isolate patients in a separate room?
questions.explanation: caused by the Measles virus . It spreads via respiratory droplets and can remain infectious in the air for up to 2 hours after an infected person leaves the room. Isolation in a separate negative pressure room (airborne infection isolation room) is necessary to prevent its spread. Rabies (Option B) is transmitted through bites or saliva of infected animals, not through the airborne route. Therefore, patient isolation in a separate room is not required. Nipah (Option C): Nipah virus is primarily transmitted via close contact with infected animals or individuals, as well as their body fluids. Airborne transmission is rare, and isolation precautions usually involve contact and droplet precautions , not necessarily airborne isolation. Aseptic meningitis (Option D) is usually caused by viruses such as Enteroviruses , which are transmitted via the fecal-oral route or droplets. Airborne isolation is not required. Reference: Park’s Preventive and Social medicine, 27th edition, Page 164-165 Nelson Textbook of Paediatrics, 21st Edition, Page 1673, 1674

questions.question: What are the necessary criteria that need to be fulfilled in order to initiate MDT? 1. Hypopigmented patch with sensory loss 2. Peripheral nerve thickening 3. Peripheral nerve thickening with sensory loss 4. Skin biopsy demonstrating bacilli
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, 4 Explanation According to the WHO guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of leprosy , Multidrug Therapy (MDT) can be initiated without biopsy if clinical features are clearly suggestive. The diagnosis of leprosy - and therefore the decision to initiate MDT — can be made if at least one of the following is present : Diagnostic Criteria for Leprosy 1. Hypopigmented or reddish skin lesion with definite sensory loss 2. Thickened peripheral nerve with sensory and/or motor loss 3. Positive slit-skin smear or skin biopsy showing AFB Hence, to start MDT: Option 1 : Hypopigmented patch with sensory loss → sufficient Option 3 : Peripheral nerve thickening with sensory loss → sufficient Option 4 : Skin biopsy showing bacilli → sufficient Peripheral nerve thickening only (Option 2) : Not sufficient alone unless accompanied by sensory or motor loss . Reference: https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/leprosy

questions.question: What is the accurate statement concerning preventive measures for typhoid transmission in the community?

options.A: Typhoid vaccine administration is the best method of preventing transmission.
options.B: Hygiene practice and clean sanitation control is more important than the typhoid vaccine.
options.C: In 10% of cases, person-to-person transmission occurs.
options.D: Drug resistance in typhoid is not as big a problem as in TB.

questions.explanation: typhoid vaccine. of typhoid. Proper sanitation, clean drinking water, and good hygiene practices (like hand washing) are essential in controlling the spread of the disease. While the typhoid vaccine can help prevent infection, it does not address the root causes of transmission, which are primarily linked to contaminated water and food. Typhoid vaccine administration is the best method of preventing transmission (Option A) : While the typhoid vaccine is important in preventing infection, it does not address the underlying transmission routes, which are more effectively controlled by sanitation and hygiene measures. Therefore, it is not the best method of preventing transmission alone. In 10% of cases, person-to-person transmission occurs (Option C) : This is incorrect. Typhoid is primarily spread through contaminated food and water (fecal-oral route). Person-to-person transmission is less common. Drug resistance in typhoid is not as big a problem as in TB (Option D) : This is incorrect. Drug resistance, particularly multidrug-resistant Salmonella typhi , is an increasing concern in typhoid treatment, and it is considered a significant public health challenge. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 276-280

questions.question: The drug shown in the image below is administered for:
questions.explanation: malaria . Artesunate is an effective antimalarial drug that belongs to the class of artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs). Sulfadoxine and Pyrimethamine are used together as a combination therapy for treating uncomplicated malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1242247/ Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th Edition, Page 302

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding drugs used in anti-tubercular treatment are true? A. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis B. Pyrazinamide is an enzyme inducer C. Rifampicin is used only in the treatment of tuberculosis D. Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase
questions.explanation: specifically inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acid , a key component of the mycobacterial cell wall. This mechanism is critical for its effectiveness against Mycobacterium tuberculosis . D. Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase : True . Bedaquiline is a newer anti-tubercular drug that specifically targets mycobacterial ATP synthase , disrupting energy production in the bacteria. It is used for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). B. Pyrazinamide is an enzyme inducer : False . Pyrazinamide is not an enzyme inducer. It works by disrupting mycobacterial membrane function and energy production. Rifampicin, not pyrazinamide, is a strong enzyme inducer. C. Rifampicin is used only in the treatment of tuberculosis : False . Rifampicin is used for other conditions besides tuberculosis, including leprosy, meningococcal prophylaxis, and certain staphylococcal infections . It is not exclusive to tuberculosis treatment. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 211

questions.question: A child is brought to the PHC with acute diarrhoea. The doctor, based on history, suspects that the child may be suffering from an infection due to Shigella over cholera and proceeds to give ciprofloxacin as the antibiotic. Which of the following points on history, apart from bloody stools, favour the doctor's suspicion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Presence of fever Fever is more commonly associated with Shigella infection rather than cholera. Shigella infection can cause a systemic inflammatory response, leading to fever. Cholera, on the other hand, typically does not cause a significant fever. Therefore, the presence of fever supports the doctor's suspicion of a Shigella infection and favors it over cholera. Clinical Presentation of Shigella: Diarrhea: Typically acute and often bloody (dysentery). Incubation Period: 1-3 days after exposure. Prodromal Period: 1-2 days after the incubation period. Abdominal Pain: Severe cramping. Fever: Often high-grade. Tenesmus: Painful straining with defecation. Systemic Symptoms: Malaise, headache, and sometimes vomiting. Absence of rectal pain (Option A): Rectal pain is not a specific symptom that distinguishes between Shigella infection and cholera. Both conditions can cause diarrhea without necessarily causing rectal pain. Presence of abdominal cramps (Option B): Abdominal cramps are commonly associated with both Shigella infection and cholera. Presence of vomiting (Option C): While it can be present in both infections, it is not specific to Shigella and does not strongly favor one diagnosis over the other Learning objective

questions.question: What is the most reliable indicator of recent malaria transmission?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Infant parasite rate The Infant parasite rate refers to the proportion of infants or young children who are infected with malaria parasites. Infants are particularly susceptible to malaria infection, and their infection rates can be a reliable indicator of recent malaria transmission within a community. The infant parasite rate (IPR) is the most sensitive indicator of recent malaria transmission in a population. If the IPR remains 0 for 3 consecutive years, the population can be considered free from malaria transmission. Note: The vectors responsible for previous malaria transmission in a population will not be included in the IPR results. Spleen rate (Option A): The spleen rate is an indicator of chronic or long-term malaria infection. Parasite density index (Option C): The parasite density index reflects the intensity of infection in individuals but may not be as sensitive for assessing recent transmission on a population level. Slide positivity rate (Option D): is commonly used as an indicator of malaria prevalence and can provide insights into ongoing transmission. However, the Infant parasite rate is considered to be a more sensitive index for recent transmission. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Page 306

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for a 50-year-old male who worked in the dye industry and had exposure to aniline dyes, and is now experiencing bladder problems?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Transitional cell carcinoma In the above case, the individual has been exposed to aniline dye and the most probable cancer in this patient is bladder cancer or transitional cell carcinoma. Chemical Carcinogens Associated Cancers: Chemical Cancer Note Aflatoxin Hepatocellular Carcinoma Aspergillus; stored grains Alkylating Agents Lymphoma & Leukemia Caused by chemotherapy Alcohol SCC of Oropharynx/Esophagus, Pancreatic Ca, HCC — Arsenic SCC of Skin, Angiosarcoma of Liver, Lung Ca Contained in cigarette smoke Cigarette Smoke Bladder, Lung, Oropharynx, Kidney, Esophagus Polycyclic hydrocarbons Nitrosamines Stomach Ca Smoked foods, Japan Napthylamine Urothelial (bladder) Ca Comes from cigarette smoke Vinyl Chloride Angiosarcoma of liver Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipes Chromium, Beryllium, Nickel, Silica Lung Ca — Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK13216/

questions.question: Based on Globocan 2020 data, which cancer type is the most prevalent among males in India?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Lip and oral cavity According to Globocan 2020, the most common cancer in males in India is lip and oral cavity cancer. According to the Global Cancer Observatory (GLOBOCAN), Most common cancer worldwide (Both Genders): Absolute numbers, Incidence, Both sexes, in 2022 (World Wide)- Lung Cancer. Age-Standardized Rate (World) per 100 000, Incidence, Both sexes, in 2022- Breast Cancer. Most common cancer in India in terms of absolute numbers, incidence: Lip/Oral Cancer in Males Breast cancer in females According to the National Cancer Registry, the most common cause of cancer in Males in India – Lung cancer. Females in India - Breast cancer. Important Ribbon Colors: Ribbon colour Meaning Red HIV/AIDS Pink Breast cancer Light Blue Prostate cancer Dark Blue Colon Cancer Green Mental illness Liver cancer Orange/Yellow Suicide prevention Leukaemia Kidney cancer White Lung cancer Reference: https://ncdirindia.org/All_Reports/Report_2020/default.aspx https://gco.iarc.who.int/media/globocan/factsheets/populations/356-india-fact-sheet.pdf

questions.question: A pregnant woman arrived at the emergency department following an incident where she was scratched by a stray dog while walking on the streets one hour ago. She has only suffered minor abrasions without any bleeding. What course of treatment should be provided to her?

options.A: No treatment as she is pregnant now
options.C: Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine
options.D: Local wound cleaning, Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins

questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine: The patient falls under Category II according to WHO since there is no bleeding therefore she has to be administered rabies vaccine along with local wound cleaning. Rabies being a lethal disease, there is no contraindication for post exposure prophylaxis. Management of rabies wound: Category Exposure Management Class I (Option B) Licks and touch on intact skin (skin integrity not broken) Local wound management: soap, running water, iodine tincture for 15-20 min. Class II Abrasion, laceration (skin integrity broken) Local wound management Immediate Rabies vaccination Class III (Option D) Bleeding, licks on mucosa/ broken skin, deep tissue injury, all wild animal or bat bite Wound management (avoid suturing) Rabies vaccination Rabies immunoglobulin No treatment as she is pregnant now (Option A): Rabies is a lethal disease and hence has no post exposure prophylaxis contraindication, not even pregnancy. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg: 324-327

questions.question: What treatment should be administered to a patient diagnosed with P. Falciparum malaria from a North-Eastern state?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Artemether plus lumefantrine P. falciparum malaria in India, especially in regions like the North-Eastern states , is often chloroquine-resistant. The recommended treatment for P. falciparum malaria is a combination therapy with Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT) to prevent resistance and ensure effective treatment. Artemether plus lumefantrine is one of the ACT regimens recommended Treatment of severe/complicated malaria: Initial parenteral treatment (48 hours) Follow-up treatment Quinine Loading dose: 20 mg/kg Maintenance dose : 10 mg/kg TDS Quinine 10 mg/kg TDS + Doxycycline 3 mg/kg (or) Clindamycin 10 mg/kg (if pregnant / children < 8 years) Total treatment duration: 7 days Artesunate : 2.4 mg/kg loading dose, then at 12th and 24th hour followed by once a day. Artemether : Loading dose of 3.2 mg/kg; maintenance dose of 1.6 mg/kg per day. Arteether : 150 mg per day for 3 days. ACT therapy North-eastern states: Age & weight adjusted ACT-AL for 3 days + primaquine on second day. Other states: ACT-SP (Option B) (sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine) for 3 days + primaquine on second day. Chloroquine (Option C): Is mainly used in treatment of infection by P. vivax and P. ovale with dosage of 25 mg/kg body weight (Mnemonic - VOC i.e. For Vivax and ovale → Chloroquine is used). Mefloquine (Option D) : This is an alternative ACT but is not the first-line recommendation in this scenario. Is effective against chloroquine-resistant forms of P. falciparum. Also used for chemoprophylaxis of malaria. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Pages 311,312,313

questions.question: Re-infection with which of the following will lead to catastrophic symptoms even in the presence of antibodies?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Dengue Re-infection with Dengue can lead to catastrophic symptoms even in the presence of antibodies, due to antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE). When an individual is re-exposed to a different Dengue serotype, the immune response can trigger severe forms such as Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever or Dengue Shock Syndrome, leading to life-threatening complications. Re-infection and Antibody-Dependent Enhancement in Dengue: First Exposure: Leads to immune sensitization to Dengue virus. Re-exposure: With a different Dengue serotype (e.g., DENV-2) can trigger antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE). Outcome: ADE can lead to severe Dengue, Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF), or Dengue Shock Syndrome (DSS). Mechanism: Cross-reactive antibodies from the first infection enhance the severity of the disease during the second infection. Result: Increased risk of severe illness due to immune system overreaction to the second Dengue serotype. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3185591/

questions.question: Which kit would you recommend for the treatment of a 20-year-old female who has recently engaged in sexual intercourse and is experiencing vaginal discharge and lower abdominal pain when following the syndromic management approach for sexually transmitted infections at the Suraksha clinic in the local primary health center?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Yellow Lower abdominal pain with vaginal discharge indicative of PID (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease). Hence, the kit to be prescribed is a yellow kit that covers the syndrome. Colour-coded STD kits along with medicines: Kit Colour Indication Medicines 1 Grey Urethral discharge Cervicitis Ano-rectal discharge Azithromycin, cefixime 2 Green Vaginitis Secnidazole, fluconazole 3 White Non-herpetic genital ulcers Azithromycin, B. Penicillin 4 Blue (Option A) Genital ulcers Penicillin allergy + Azithromycin, doxycycline 5 Red (Option B) Herpetic genital ulcers Acyclovir 6 Yellow Lower abdominal pain Cefixime metronidazole, doxycycline 7 Black (Option C) Inguinal bubo Azithromycin, doxycycline 8 Brown Anorectal discharge syndrome Cefixime, doxycycline Reference: Park textbook of preventive and social medicine, 25th edition, Pg. no. 472, 362.

questions.question: You are a doctor in a village. A 1-year-old child who is not taking feeds presents with fever and cough for 2 days. On examination, he is calm, with a respiratory rate of 51 breaths/min, and stridor is present. According to IMNCI (integrated management of neonatal and childhood illnesses). How is he classified?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Severe pneumonia A calm child with stridor and fast breathing in the age group of 2 months- 5 years is classified as having Severe Pneumonia (Options A and B ruled out) ARDS (Option D): ARDS is not classified under IMNCI guidelines. It is a critical care diagnosis based on specific criteria such as: Acute onset of respiratory distress. Bilateral infiltrates on chest imaging. PaO I /FiO I ratio ≤ 300 mmHg. Reference: Pneumonia guidelines- NHM

questions.question: What type of resistance is exhibited by the patient who is unresponsive to Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Ofloxacin, and Kanamycin?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Extensively drug-resistant Extensively drug-resistant (XDR) is a term used to describe a type of resistance in which the microorganism is resistant to a wide range of antibiotics, including those considered first-line and second-line treatment options. The patient's resistance to Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Ofloxacin, and Kanamycin indicates an extensive resistance pattern, meeting the criteria for XDR. Classification of TB Patients Based on Drug Testing Category Description Drug sensitive TB Patients are sensitive to 4 TB drugs: R,H,Z,E (Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol). Mono-resistant (MR) Resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only. H-Mono-resistant (H-MR) Resistant to Isoniazid (H) only. Rifampicin resistant (RR) (Option C) Resistant to Rifampicin (R) only. Multi-drug resistant (MDR) (Option A) Resistant to both Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H). Poly-Drug resistant (PDR) Resistant to 2 drugs other than Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H). Pre-Xtensive resistant (pre-XDR) Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone. Extensive resistant (XDR) Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone and Group 4 drugs (Bedaquiline, Linezolid, Levo/Moxifloxacin). Extremely drug-resistant (Option D): It is likely a variation of the term "extensively drug resistant" (as seen in option b), but it is not a commonly used or accepted term in the context of drug resistance. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition Pg 211

questions.question: A diabetic patient comes to you for advice regarding his diet. You advise him to include foods with a low glycemic index in the diet. Which of the following would you advise him for the same?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Papaya A diabetic patient should include low glycemic index (GI) foods in their diet, as these foods cause a slower and more gradual rise in blood sugar levels. From the options provided: Papaya : Low GI (55 or less) – Recommended for diabetic patients. Classification GI Index Range Examples Low GI 55 or less Most fruits and vegetables (except potatoes, watermelon, sweetcorn), whole grains, pasta foods, beans, lentils, oats, quinoa, guava Medium GI 56-69 Sucrose, basmati rice, brown rice, dairy products (Options B, C) High GI 70 and above Corn flakes, baked potato, some white rice varieties (e.g., jasmine), white bread, candy bar, syrupy foods (Options A) Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4994556/

questions.question: Please match the following colors of STI kits with their corresponding use: A. Lower abdominal pain B. Urethral discharge C. Non herpetic genital ulcer D. Vaginal discharge 1. Grey, Kit 1 2. Green, Kit 2 3. White, Kit 3 4. Yellow, Kit 6
questions.explanation: Urethral discharge 1. Grey, Kit 1 C. Non-herpetic genital ulcer 3. White, Kit 3 D. Vaginal discharge 2. Green, Kit 2 Colour-coded STD kits along with medicines: Kit Colour Indication Medicines 1 Grey Urethral discharge Cervicitis Ano-rectal discharge Azithromycin, cefixime 2 Green Vaginitis Secnidazole, fluconazole 3 White Non-herpetic genital ulcers Azithromycin, B. Penicillin 4 Blue Genital ulcers Penicillin allergy + Azithromycin, doxycycline 5 Red Herpetic genital ulcers Acyclovir 6 Yellow Lower abdominal pain Cefixime metronidazole, doxycycline 7 Black Inguinal bubo Azithromycin, doxycycline 8 Brown Anorectal discharge syndrome Cefixime, doxycycline Incorrect Options: Option A, C & D are incorrect Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 159

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the rise in the occurrence of non-communicable diseases observed in recent years?
questions.explanation: typically indicates a gradual and persistent increase or decrease in the incidence or prevalence of a particular condition over many years or decades. In the given scenario, the increase in the incidence of non-communicable diseases over the past few years suggests a long-term and sustained change in the prevalence of these diseases. This pattern is consistent with a secular trend, as it indicates a significant shift in disease burden over an extended period of time. Incorrect Options: Seasonal (Option A): Seasonal trends refer to patterns that occur within a specific season or time of the year. Therefore, this option is not appropriate for the given scenario. Cyclical (Option B): The scenario does not describe a cyclical pattern as the increase in non-communicable diseases is not occurring in a cyclic or predictable manner. Periodic (Option C): The scenario does not suggest that the increase in non-communicable diseases is occurring at regular intervals or in a repeated fashion. Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25, page no: 72-74

questions.question: Which of the following does not require precautions for airborne transmission?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Herpes Zoster: Herpes Zoster (shingles) typically does not require airborne precautions unless it is disseminated (spreading across multiple dermatomes or in an immunocompromised host). In its localized form, transmission occurs through direct contact with the fluid from the lesions, so standard precautions are sufficient. Airborne precautions are required for diseases transmitted via fine respiratory droplets that remain suspended in the air for long periods. These diseases include: Tuberculosis (Option A) : Airborne transmission; precautions are mandatory. Measles (Option C) : Highly contagious and transmitted through airborne droplets; precautions are necessary. Chickenpox (Varicella) (Option D) : Airborne and contact transmission; precautions are required. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25578684/

questions.question: What is the serum level of tetanus antitoxin required for clinical protection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - >0.01 IU/ml. Tetanus antitoxin levels in the serum indicate immunity against tetanus. A protective level of tetanus antitoxin is defined as ≥ 0.01 IU/ml , according to the World Health Organization (WHO). This level is sufficient to neutralize the tetanus toxin and provide clinical protection. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 25, Page 340

questions.question: What is the recommended treatment for a resident doctor who experiences a needlestick injury while attending to an HIV positive patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Indinavir Explanation: For a healthcare worker exposed to HIV, such as through a needlestick injury, the recommended treatment is Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) . PEP involves a combination of antiretroviral drugs to reduce the likelihood of HIV transmission. Current Recommendations: Preferred PEP regimen typically includes a combination of two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) like Zidovudine + Lamivudine and a third drug, which is a protease inhibitor (PI) such as Indinavir or an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI) like Dolutegravir or Raltegravir . The regimen must be started as soon as possible, ideally within 2 hours , and continued for 28 days Zidovudine + Lamivudine (Option A) : This is a 2-drug regimen, which is suboptimal for PEP, as it lacks a third drug, typically an INSTI like Dolutegravir , which is recommended for improved efficacy. Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Nevirapine (Option B) : Nevirapine is an older non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) that is associated with more adverse effects and drug resistance, making it less preferable for PEP in modern guidelines. Zidovudine + Nevirapine (Option D) : This is also a 2-drug regimen and lacks a third drug (an INSTI like Dolutegravir), which is essential for optimal PEP. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, Edition 21, Page 1594, 1595

questions.question: What type of vaccine is the Diphtheria vaccine?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Toxoid Explanation: The Diphtheria vaccine is a toxoid vaccine . Toxoid vaccines are made from inactivated toxins produced by bacteria. These toxins are treated to remove their harmful effects while still stimulating the immune system to recognize and fight the toxin if exposed in the future. For diphtheria , the causative agent Corynebacterium diphtheriae produces a potent toxin that causes the disease. The vaccine contains an inactivated form of this toxin (diphtheria toxoid), which prompts the body to develop immunity without causing the disease. Polysaccharide vaccine (Option A) : Polysaccharide vaccines use sugar molecules from the surface of bacteria to stimulate immunity. Diphtheria is not a polysaccharide vaccine. Killed vaccine (Option C) : Killed vaccines use whole pathogens (bacteria or viruses) that are killed or inactivated, but diphtheria is a toxoid vaccine, not a killed bacteria vaccine. Live attenuated vaccine (Option D) : Live attenuated vaccines use a weakened form of the pathogen, but diphtheria vaccines do not contain live bacteria. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 25, Page 111

questions.question: Which one of the following methods does not effectively prevent the transmission of COVID-19?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1% glutaraldehyde Explanation: 1% glutaraldehyde : 1% glutaraldehyde is a chemical used for disinfecting medical instruments, but it is not recommended for general hand hygiene or preventing the transmission of COVID-19. Alcohol-based hand sanitizers or soap and water are far more effective for personal hygiene. Face mask (Option A) : Wearing a face mask is an effective measure for preventing the transmission of COVID-19, especially when combined with other protective actions, as it helps reduce the spread of respiratory droplets that may contain the virus. 70% alcohol (Option C) : Alcohol-based hand sanitizers containing 70% alcohol are highly effective in killing the coronavirus on the hands, reducing the risk of transmission. Hand washing (Option D) : Regular hand washing with soap and water is one of the most effective ways to prevent the spread of COVID-19, as it helps remove the virus from the skin. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10607620/

questions.question: What is the next course of action in managing a 24-month-old child weighing 11 kg who was presented to the pediatric OPD with a respiratory rate of 38/min and chest indrawing observed during examination?

options.B: Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately
options.C: Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.explanation: a respiratory rate of 38/min and chest indrawing is suggestive of pneumonia. The management for pneumonia recommended is oral antibiotics for five days (Amoxicillin/ cotrimoxazole syrup) and home care advice. WHO Classification of Pneumonia (IMNCI Guidelines) Clinical Signs Classification Treatment / Action No fast breathing, no chest indrawing, no danger No pneumonia Home care, fluids, continued feeding, follow-up Fast breathing and/or chest indrawing Pneumonia Oral amoxicillin, home care, follow-up Any general danger sign* or stridor in calm child Severe pneumonia Injectable antibiotics, urgent referral to hospital *General danger signs: Not able to drink/breastfeed, persistent vomiting, convulsions, lethargy/unconsciousness, stridor in calm child, severe malnutrition. Revised WHO classification (and updated IMNCI guidelines) now include only two categories for pneumonia in children 2–59 months: Pneumonia: Fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, without general danger signs- managed with oral amoxicillin at home. Severe pneumonia: Any general danger sign or stridor in a calm child- managed with injectable antibiotics and urgent referral. Oral amoxicillin has replaced cotrimoxazole as the first-line antibiotic for pneumonia. Chest indrawing without danger signs is no longer classified as severe pneumonia; it is managed at home with oral antibiotics Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately (Option B): Is recommended in case of severe pneumonia. Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours (Option C): Is not a considerable option in case of pneumonia. Start antipyretics urgently (Option D): Is not recommended in case of any pneumonia. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK264162/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK264164/ https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/137332/WHO_FWC_MCA_14.9_eng.pdf

questions.question: According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, which of the following does not meet the criteria for metabolic syndrome?
questions.explanation: Treatment Panel III (NCEP-ATP III) criteria, the criterion that is not included in the definition of metabolic syndrome is: High LDL (Low-density lipoprotein) NCEP-ATP III criteria include: Central obesity (Option C) Hypertriglyceridemia (Option A) Hypertension (Option D) Impaired fasting glucose or type 2 diabetes Reference: Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition Pg 40

questions.question: The patient presents with a clean-cut injury that is not torn. He mentions receiving a tetanus vaccination approximately 10 years ago. What is the appropriate course of action?
questions.explanation: prophylaxis, if a patient has received a complete primary vaccination series (usually consists of three doses) and has had a booster dose within the past 10 years, a single booster dose of tetanus toxoid is recommended for clean, minor wounds or injuries. Incorrect Options: Full course of tetanus vaccination & Tetanus toxoid + immunoglobulin (Option A and C): Since the patient's injury is clean-cut and not lacerated, a full course of tetanus vaccination or tetanus toxoid with immunoglobulin is not necessary. Non vaccination needed (Option D): Non-vaccination is also not recommended as the patient's last dose was received 10 years ago, and a booster dose is required in this situation. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition Pg 40

questions.question: What is the association of Project MONICA?
questions.explanation: and determinants in Cardiovascular disease) is an international collaborative study that aimed to monitor trends and investigate determinants of cardiovascular diseases. It involved multiple countries and regions and collected data on various aspects related to cardiovascular health, such as incidence, mortality, risk factors, and preventive measures. Incorrect Options: Option B, C & D are incorrect Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition Pg 40

questions.question: Which influenza virus caused the pandemic that took place in 2009?
questions.explanation: pandemic, commonly known as the "swine flu" pandemic, was caused by a novel strain of the influenza A virus subtype H1N1. It was first identified in Mexico in April 2009 and quickly spread worldwide, leading to a declaration of a global pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO) in June 2009. The H1N1 virus strain was a combination of swine, avian, and human influenza viruses, and it caused significant illness and mortality globally during that time. Incorrect Options: Option B, C & D are incorrect Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition Pg 860

questions.question: What is the duration after which the polymorphic rash of Varicella is no longer contagious?
questions.explanation: varicella extends until the lesions have completely crusted over. Once the crusts have formed and the vesicles are no longer fluid-filled, the risk of transmission decreases significantly. At this stage, the virus is considered less contagious, and the individual is generally considered non-infectious. Epidemiological factors of chicken pox: Agent Varicella-zoster virus (HHV 3- Human Herpes Virus 3) Double-stranded DNA virus. Source of infection Scabs are not infectious, but the vesicular fluid is infectious. (Option D) Airborne- spreads via both droplet infection and droplet nuclei Period of communicability 1-2 days before and 4-5 days after the onset of the rash (crust formation) Secondary attack rate- 85% Host factors Age: <10 years Very common in school-going children One attack gives lifelong immunity Reactivation can occur as Varicella zoster infection in later age Environmental factors More common in winter and early spring The virus can survive outside the body for 24-48 hours. Disinfectants easily kill the virus. Incubation period More common in winter and early spring The virus can survive outside the body for 24-48 hours. Disinfectants easily kill the virus. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pages 161, 162

questions.question: Komal, a 2-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a high fever, cough, red eyes, and rash. Parents say that the rash started on the forehead and behind the ears, then subsequently spread to the neck and body. On examination, a confluent maculopapular rash is noted as shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this child's condition?

options.A: The period of infectivity is 3 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash
options.B: The most common cause of death is subacute sclerosing panencephalitis
options.C: Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are associated with the disease

questions.explanation: rare complication of measles infection, occurring years after the initial infection. It is characterized by progressive inflammation and degeneration of the brain. While SSPE is a serious condition, it is not the most common cause of death in children with measles. Measles Causative agent ssRNA paramyxovirus Incubation period 10 days from exposure to onset of fever and 14 days to the appearance of rash Source of infection Person with measles Infective material Period of communicability Roughly 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash (Option A ruled out) Clinical features Prodromal stage : Fever Cough Coryza with sneezing Conjunctivitis with lacrimation Koplik’s spots- grayish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Pathognomonic feature) (Option D ruled out) Eruptive stage : Dusky red macular/maculopapular rash, which starts behind the ears and progresses to the face, neck and then to trunks and limbs. In the absence of complications, the lesions and fever disappear after 3-4 days. Post measles stage: After the eruptive stage, it leads to weight loss, weakness, fatigue, diarrhea. Isolation period 7 days from the onset of rash Difference between measles and rubella rash Both rashes are maculopapular The rash in measles is more confluent and botchy, whereas the rash in rubella is discrete or non-confluent. Diagnosis

questions.question: Within what time frame should Cholera, a disease that requires notification, be reported to the World Health Organization?
questions.explanation: reported to the World Health Organization (WHO) within 24 hours. This allows for early detection, investigation, and response to cholera outbreaks, which is essential for minimizing the impact on public health. Notifiable diseases: Notifiable diseases in India include diseases that are contagious, severe, or frequent, and require health providers to report them to public health officials. List of Notifiable diseases in India Note: the list is not comprehensive AIDS Dengue fever Hepatitis B Malaria Whooping cough (Pertussis) Rabies Tetanus Viral encephalitis Anemia Chickenpox Diphtheria Influenza Measles Plague Smallpox Tuberculosis Malnutrition Iodine deficiency Cholera Hepatitis A Leprosy Cerebro spinal fever Polio Scarlet fever Typhoid fever Vitamin A deficiency Reference: https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/documents/emergencies/who-guidance-for-use-of-annex-2.pdf https://tnhealth.tn.gov.in/tngovin/dph/dphdbnoti.php

questions.question: Zika virus is transmitted by:
questions.explanation: patients with acute onset of fever, maculopapular rash, and arthralgia, particularly if they have travelled to areas with ongoing transmission in the two weeks before symptom onset. Zica virus is transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito. Zika virus disease: Agent: Zika virus is a Flavivirus transmitted via mosquito bite; hence, it is called an arbovirus. Mode of Transmission: Transmitted by the bite of an infected Aedes aegypti mosquito, which tends to bite during the morning and late afternoon. It is also increasingly recognized that an infected pregnant woman can pass the virus to her baby during pregnancy or near the time of birth. Clinical Symptoms: Fever, skin rash, conjunctivitis, joint pain, headache. Symptoms are usually mild and last 2-7 days. Prevention: Prevention and control depend on reducing mosquitoes through the removal and modification of breeding sites. Culex mosquito (Option B): Primarily known for transmitting West Nile virus and other arboviruses. Anopheles mosquito (Option C): Primarily known for transmitting malaria. Phlebotomus (Option D): It is a sandfly known for transmitting Kala-azar. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg 321, 351-52

questions.question: Which among the following regions is free from rabies?
questions.explanation: with water. In India, rabies is not found in islands such as Andaman and Nicobar Islands and Lakshadweep. Epidemiological Determinants of Rabies: Agent factor Zoonotic disease with a 100% fatality rate Lyssavirus type 1 Bullet-shaped RNA virus (Rhabdoviridae family). Two Types of Viruses: Street virus: Cause natural infection (Rabies) Variable incubation period (7 days-months) Fixed virus: Fixed incubation period (5-7 days) For vaccine production. It does not demonstrate Negri bodies. Host factors Occupation Dog handlers Forest workers Veterinarians. Transmission Incubation period: 2-8 weeks Animal bite: Dog, Cat, Monkey or Wild animal (all need vaccination) Licks on abraded skin are considered as the route of transmission. Rodent bites don't require vaccination. Human bite is a very dangerous bite (no documented cases yet) In India: Urban Rabies is very common. Rabies is not found around water-bounded areas (Lakshadweep and Andaman and Nicobar Islands) (Option C) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg: 322-323

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presented to the hospital with fever, dry cough, sore throat, and muscle pain. RT-PCR confirmed the patient to be positive for COVID 19. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the epidemiology of Covid-19? ≥ 50 years ≥ 80 years

options.C: Mode of transmission is droplets, contacts
options.D: Remdesivir is an emergency use authorization (EUA) from the FDA for COVID-19

questions.explanation: ≥ 50 years ≥ 50 years: The incorrect statement is "1% Case Fatality rate in age ≥ 50 years." In reality, the case fatality rate for COVID-19 is generally higher in older age groups, especially in individuals aged 50 years and above. Older age is considered a significant risk factor for severe illness and mortality from COVID-19. Incorrect Options: Option B - 5% Case Fatality rate in age ≥ 80 years: This statement is generally true. The case fatality rate tends to increase with age, and individuals aged 80 years and above are at higher risk of severe illness and mortality. Option C - Mode of transmission is droplets, contacts: This statement is generally true. COVID-19 primarily spreads through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs, sneezes, talks, or breathes. It can also spread by close contact with an infected person or through contact with contaminated surfaces or objects. Option D - Remdesivir is an emergency use authorization (EUA) from the FDA for COVID-19: This statement is correct. Remdesivir initially received emergency use authorization (EUA) from the FDA for the treatment of hospitalized COVID-19 patients, However is no longer considered the recommended or first-line treatment for COVID-19 in many countries. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A patient from a North-Eastern state was diagnosed to have an infection with P. falciparum malaria. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: the treatment of uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria. Artemether is an artemisinin derivative that rapidly kills malaria parasites, while lumefantrine is a longer-acting antimalarial drug that helps to clear the remaining parasites and prevent the development of resistance. This combination is effective against P. falciparum and is widely used as a first-line treatment in many regions. Incorrect options Option B . Sulfadoxine plus pyrimethamine: This combination was historically used as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated malaria caused by P. falciparum. However, due to the widespread development of resistance to this combination, it is no longer recommended as a first-line treatment in many regions, including areas with high P. falciparum prevalence. Resistance to sulfadoxine plus pyrimethamine has limited its effectiveness as an antimalarial therapy. Option C. Chloroquine: Chloroquine was once the drug of choice for the treatment of malaria, including P. falciparum malaria. However, the emergence of chloroquine-resistant strains of P. falciparum has rendered chloroquine ineffective in many parts of the world, including North-Eastern states. It is no longer recommended as a first-line treatment for P. falciparum malaria in areas where resistance is prevalent. Option D. Mefloquine: Mefloquine is an antimalarial drug primarily used as a prophylactic treatment to prevent malaria in individuals traveling to endemic regions. While it can also be used for the treatment of malaria, it is typically considered an alternative option rather than a first-line treatment. Its use may be warranted in specific cases or regions where resistance to other antimalarials is present. Reference: .
